linkTarget.anchoringText: Performance Summary of Active Wells (Figure 1): Maps and trends of oil, gas, and water production; well vintage and grouping analyses, by layer and block. These analytics provide a quick, automated framing analysis of reservoir trends.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Automated well grouping analysis. Average Oil Production Rate Active Well Count Oil EUR vs Time, LocationType Basic Decline, Operation and New Wells (Analysis at January 2013)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Automated well grouping analysis. Average Oil Production Rate Active Well Count Oil EUR vs Time, LocationType Basic Decline, Operation and New Wells (Analysis at January 2013)

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Basic Decline, Operation and New Wells (Analysis at January 2013)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Offline Well Analysis (Figure 2): Special emphasis is given to wells currently offline, which often present the quickest and easiest opportunities to raise production. The cause of each wellâ€™s shutin is characterized based on trends in water cut (WCUT), gas/oil ratio (GOR), and pressure (e.g. a rapid increase in WCUT is flagged as a well watering-out). These analytics will lead to specific opportunities to restore production from offline wells.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Offline well analysis. Oil Rate Before Shut-in [STB/D] Water Cut Before Shut-in [%] Wells Shut-In and Probable Cause

formatted-caption.caption-text: Offline well analysis. Oil Rate Before Shut-in [STB/D] Water Cut Before Shut-in [%] Wells Shut-In and Probable Cause

linkTarget.anchoringText: Decline Curve Analysis (Figure 3): The accuracy of automated decline curve analysis is improved through automated event detection, wherein trend breakpoints are detected mathematically (Castineira et al., 2014). These breakpoints may correspond to specific well events such as a choke change or workover; a field event, such as a change in backpressure; or a downhole event, such as a change in flow regime or drive mechanism. Any of these causes will necessitate a discreet decline curve fit, which is necessary for both future forecasting of each well, and for development of type curves to be applied for that well type or lift mechanism. Remaining reserves are estimated by well, and trends in EUR and PDP are identified by layer and block.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Automated decline curve analysis using event detection. Event Detection Annual Decline Rate (30-Sep-2015) Well Remaining Oil Vs. Cum Oil

formatted-caption.caption-text: Automated decline curve analysis using event detection. Event Detection Annual Decline Rate (30-Sep-2015) Well Remaining Oil Vs. Cum Oil

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Well Remaining Oil Vs. Cum Oil

linkTarget.anchoringText: Reservoir Contact Analysis (Figure 4): Analytics and statistics describing reservoir contact are performed for all wells over time, by zone, accounting for well type and lift mechanism. This analysis combines data from the completions, formation tops, and production/injection databases to automatically characterize the completion contact on a layer basis. Metrics such as contact intensity (ft/MMstb), defined as cumulative length of contact in a layer divided by its oil in place, allow missed opportunities to be identified for future targeting.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Completion contact by zone. Active Wells Contact by Interval (Km) Completed Contact by Interval, Active Wells Contact vs Rock Quality for Active Wells

formatted-caption.caption-text: Completion contact by zone. Active Wells Contact by Interval (Km) Completed Contact by Interval, Active Wells Contact vs Rock Quality for Active Wells

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Completed Contact by Interval, Active Wells
Contact vs Rock Quality for Active Wells

linkTarget.anchoringText: Flow Unit Allocation (Figure 5): The flow unit allocation module estimates the production and injection for each formation, in each well, at each month, allowing a granular perspective in performance by formation and by well, which is used in many other modules of this methodology. All relevant data sets that are available are incorporated, using the workflow described below for every well, over the fieldâ€™s entire history:

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Flow unit allocation for production from commingled wells. Production Allocation by Interval Contact Production Allocation by Interval Contact Production Cums, Zone4 (MBOE)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Flow unit allocation for production from commingled wells. Production Allocation by Interval Contact Production Allocation by Interval Contact Production Cums, Zone4 (MBOE)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Stochastic Material Balance (Figure 6):): Based on the possible range of each input, a single and multi-tank material balance (Matringe et al., 2015) history match is performed stochastically, providing a range of likely outcomes and forecasts. Instantaneous and cumulative drive indices are described for each layer and block, with associated scenarios of oil in place and aquifer strength.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Stochastic material balance history matching.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Stochastic material balance history matching.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fractional Flow Analysis and Heterogeneity Index (Figure 7): The oil, gas, and water fractional flow for all wells is provided over time, with estimated source of water breakthrough provided when available. This is based on each wellâ€™s monthly production, PVT curves, and estimated reservoir pressure at each timestep. Wells are then grouped into quadrants according to the heterogeneity index (Reese, 1996), with specific wellbore solutions for the wells in each quadrant:

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Oil-water heterogeneity index.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil-water heterogeneity index.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Sweep Efficiency Estimation (Figure 8): Areal sweep, vertical sweep, and displacement efficiency are quantified using analytical correlations. Total sweep efficiency is estimated as a function of pore volumes of water injected, or pore volumes swept through aquifer influx.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Sweep efficiency modeling.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Sweep efficiency modeling.

linkTarget.anchoringText: This tool relies on a customized implementation of dynamic time warping (Sakoe and Chiba, 1978), which was originally developed to find the optimal time alignment between two time series. The algorithm was customized to take as input vetted formation top picks (i.e. manually validated/picked by a geologist) in a few key wells called pivot wells. The algorithm then proceeds to correlate these vetted interpretations from the pivot wells to their corresponding dependent wells (Figure 9). Pivot wells are critical to this tool because they provide key control data points that can assist the algorithm in areas of significant geological change due to faulting, stratigraphic pinchouts, or lateral changes in facies.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Machine-assisted stratigraphic correlation using pivot wells, with resulting correlations show on sample GR logs.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Machine-assisted stratigraphic correlation using pivot wells, with resulting correlations show on sample GR logs.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Given the corrected logs provided by the petrophysicist, and the validated/corrected stratigraphic correlation discussed above, a semi-automated workflow using Petrelâ„¢ enables the streamlined construction of a 2.5D geological model (Figure 10). These workflows allow the incorporation of hard data points from logs as well as generic depositional trends specific to each zone (e.g. major fluvial/channel orientations) to quickly create fit-for-purpose models and maps. Despite the fact that 2.5D models have lower vertical resolution (i.e. one vertical cell per stratigraphic zone) compared to conventional 3D models, they capture the same lateral trends for any given zone and have the added benefit of being relatively easy to maintain and quality check.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: 2.5D geological model.

formatted-caption.caption-text: 2.5D geological model.

linkTarget.anchoringText: First, a missed net pay log is created in every well using an algorithm that incorporates the most recent completion data together with a net pay log reflecting various petrophysical cutoffs (e.g. porosity, permeability, water saturation, etc.). The algorithm correlates perforation intervals to vertical net pay blocks so as to identify missed pay intervals that are not in communication (disconnected) from existing perforations due to vertical flow barriers (Figure 11).

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Identification of missed net pay (MNP), showing perforation location, total net pay (NP), and perfed net pay (PNP).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Identification of missed net pay (MNP), showing perforation location, total net pay (NP), and perfed net pay (PNP).

linkTarget.anchoringText: Matrix-dominated systems: The algorithm estimates a drainage radius for every well/zone by relating the completed hydrocarbon pore volume thickness (HCPVT: estimated from the logs) to the allocated EUR in the completed zone. The algorithm also calculates a drainage index (DI) for every completed zone, which is defined as the ratio of the completed HCPVT to the original HCPVT. In other words, small DIs reflect areas where only thin sand layers have been accessed/drained and therefore have more oil remaining in either overlying or underlying sand packages. Figure 12 shows examples of zone-specific drainage index grids that combine information from both the drainage radius and drainage index.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Drainage analysis map examples for matrix-dominated systems, with drainage area bubbles colored by drainage index (DI) overlaying hydrocarbon pore volume thickness (HCPVT) contours.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Drainage analysis map examples for matrix-dominated systems, with drainage area bubbles colored by drainage index (DI) overlaying hydrocarbon pore volume thickness (HCPVT) contours.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The training set used to train the model consists of past completion intervals, and the training attributes are derived/calculated specifically over these intervals. For instance, a permeability training attribute is averaged from log values extracted specifically from the completion interval. Figure 13 shows an example modelâ€™s performance during training, validation, and testing phases. Once the model is trained, the testing dataset is collected by deriving the testing attributes specifically over the target missed net pay intervals. Table 1 shows various training attributes together with their corresponding testing attributes. While neural networks can incorporate relationships between several types of attributes, their reliability greatly depends on the size of the training dataset.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Artificial neural network training, validation, and testing phases.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Artificial neural network training, validation, and testing phases.

linkTarget.anchoringText: For every opportunity, the analog well set is defined as the set of wells producing from the opportunityâ€™s target zone, and located within the spatial neighborhood (i.e. within radius R or part of N closest points), and within the temporal neighborhood (i.e. started producing within the last M years). Note that the neighborhood parameters R, N, and M are user-defined. A P10 and P90 IP/EUR is extracted from the analog well set. The P50 is calculated by interpolating the IPs/EURs of the analog wells based on weights that reflect their spatial and temporal proximity. To calculate confidence, the predicted IP/EUR from the previous step is compared to the P10, P50, and P90 IP/EUR of the analog well set as shown in Figure 14.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Confidence level estimation, with the green star representing an opportunity location and values (in white) showing IPs from offset wells producing in the same zone.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Confidence level estimation, with the green star representing an opportunity location and values (in white) showing IPs from offset wells producing in the same zone.

linkTarget.anchoringText: An economic model is prepared for all producing wells in the field, quantifying the profitability of each well at current commodity prices. This process is depicted is Figure 15, which plots the monthly income (revenue minus OPEX) of each well on the left axis, and the breakeven oil price for each well on the right axis. According to this analysis, 13 wells currently producing may have been uneconomic at the price of $43/barrel. These wells have been recommended for testing and possible shut-in or cycling, and were added to the list of available wells in the production uplift and water shut-off categories. The average water cut of these wells is 97%.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Operating income and breakeven oil price for all producing wells.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Operating income and breakeven oil price for all producing wells.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fifty-one active wells and thirteen inactive wells were identified with opportunities to raise production through wellbore rejuvenation, usually through optimization of artificial lift or improved stimulation practices. A summary of these results is shown in Figure 16, while the specific opportunities in one example well are summarized in Figure 17.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Summary of production uplift opportunities identified.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Summary of production uplift opportunities identified.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fifty-one active wells and thirteen inactive wells were identified with opportunities to raise production through wellbore rejuvenation, usually through optimization of artificial lift or improved stimulation practices. A summary of these results is shown in Figure 16, while the specific opportunities in one example well are summarized in Figure 17.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Example well identified for lift upgrade and possible stimulation.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Example well identified for lift upgrade and possible stimulation.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Thirty-six opportunities for recompletion targeting missed net pay were high-graded, with results summarized in Figure 18, and example results from one example well summarized in Figure 19. These 36 opportunities were determined during the vetting process to be high confidence and recommended for immediate implementation, although some of the opportunities required a breakeven oil price higher than $43/barrel.

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: Recompletion opportunities targeting pay behind pipe.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Recompletion opportunities targeting pay behind pipe.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Thirty-six opportunities for recompletion targeting missed net pay were high-graded, with results summarized in Figure 18, and example results from one example well summarized in Figure 19. These 36 opportunities were determined during the vetting process to be high confidence and recommended for immediate implementation, although some of the opportunities required a breakeven oil price higher than $43/barrel.

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: Example recompletion opportunity targeting pay behind pipe. Opportunity Summary Wellbore Diagram OOIP Map with Drained Areas Structure Map Offset Zone Production Structural Cross Section with Offset Zone Producers

formatted-caption.caption-text: Example recompletion opportunity targeting pay behind pipe. Opportunity Summary Wellbore Diagram OOIP Map with Drained Areas Structure Map Offset Zone Production Structural Cross Section with Offset Zone Producers

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Structural Cross Section with Offset Zone Producers

linkTarget.anchoringText: Opportunities to optimize the current waterflood were identified, relying on recompletion of existing injectors to target new zones, or conversion of offline wells to injection targeting new areas. An example recommendation for injector conversion is shown in Figure 20.

image-wrap.label: Figure 20
image-wrap.caption: Injector conversion recommendation.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Injector conversion recommendation.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Ten new drill locations were identified as infills or step-outs targeting areas and zones indicated as unswept according to ROIP mapping (see Figure 21), using a methodology closely related to the missed-netpay technique described in the Methodology section. These locations were high-graded as having high confidence, although many were found to require a breakeven oil price above $43/barrel.

image-wrap.label: Figure 21
image-wrap.caption: New drill infill location identified based on geological and ROIP mapping. Opportunity Summary Primary Target Zone OOIP Map with Drained Areas Structure Map with Offset Zone Production Offset Zone Production Structural Cross Section with Offset Zone Producers

formatted-caption.caption-text: New drill infill location identified based on geological and ROIP mapping. Opportunity Summary Primary Target Zone OOIP Map with Drained Areas Structure Map with Offset Zone Production Offset Zone Production Structural Cross Section with Offset Zone Producers
